description: From Middle English trien (‚Äúto try a legal case‚Äù), from Anglo-Norman trier (‚Äúto try a case‚Äù), Old French trier (‚Äúto choose, pick out or separate from others, sift, cull‚Äù), of uncertain origin. It is probably related to Italian tritare (‚Äúto grind; to sort; to analyze‚Äù) (see also French trier). Alternatively, believed to be a metathetic variation of Old French tirer (‚Äúto pull out, snatch‚Äù), from Gothic êçÑêåπêçÇêå∞êåΩ (tiran, ‚Äúto tear away, remove‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *teranƒÖ (‚Äúto tear, tear apart‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *der- (‚Äúto tear, tear apart‚Äù), see tear. Related to Occitan triar (‚Äúto pick out, choose from among others‚Äù), although the Occitan verb could also be a borrowing from French. Alternatively or by confluence, the Old French is from Gallo-Roman Vulgar Latin *triare, of unknown origin.

Replaced native Middle English cunnen (‚Äúto try‚Äù) (from Old English cunnian), Middle English fandien (‚Äúto try, prove‚Äù) (from Old English fandian), and Middle English costnien (‚Äúto try, tempt, test‚Äù) (from Old English costnian).

entries.meaning: An attempt.
examples: I gave unicycling a try but I couldn‚Äôt do it.

entries.meaning: An act of tasting or sampling.
examples: I gave sushi a try but I didn‚Äôt like it.

entries.meaning: (rugby) A score in rugby league and rugby union, analogous to a touchdown in American football.
examples: Today I scored my first try.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, obsolete) A screen, or sieve, for grain.
(American football) A field goal or extra point
(chess) A move that almost solves a chess problem, except that Black has a unique defense.

verbs.description: try (third-person singular simple present tries, present participle trying, simple past and past participle tried)

entries.meaning: To attempt; to endeavour. Followed by infinitive.
examples: I tried to rollerblade, but I couldn‚Äôt.
I'll come to dinner soon. I'm trying to beat this level first.

entries.meaning: To separate (precious metal etc.) from the ore by melting; to purify, refine.
(one sort from another) To winnow; to sift; to pick out; frequently followed by out.
examples: to try out the wild corn from the good

entries.meaning: (nautical) To extract oil from blubber or fat; to melt down blubber to obtain oil
To extract wax from a honeycomb
To make an experiment. Usually followed by a present participle.
examples: I tried mixing more white paint to get a lighter shade.

entries.meaning: To put to test.
examples: I shall try my skills on this.

entries.meaning: (specifically) To test someone's patience.
examples: You are trying my patience.
Don't try me.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, chiefly used in the imperative) To receive an imminent attack; to take.
examples: Mona: Try this vampire bolt on for size!
Cedric: Why don't you try this alien bolt?

entries.meaning: To taste, sample, etc.
examples: Oh, you need to try the soup of the day!

entries.meaning: To prove by experiment; to apply a test to, for the purpose of determining the quality; to examine; to prove; to test.
examples: to try weights or measures by a standard;‚ÄÉ to try a person's opinions

entries.meaning: (with indirect interrogative clause) To attempt to determine (by experiment or effort).
examples: I'll try whether I can make it across town on foot.

entries.meaning: (law) To put on trial.
examples: He was tried and executed.

entries.meaning: To have or gain knowledge of by experience.
To work on something with one's best effort and focus.
examples: Dad, for fuck's sake, I'm trying my best!
You are trying too hard.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To do; to fare.
examples: How do you try! (i.e., how do you do?)

entries.meaning: To settle; to decide; to determine; specifically, to decide by an appeal to arms.
examples: to try rival claims by a duel;‚ÄÉ to try conclusions

entries.meaning: (euphemistic, of a couple) To attempt to conceive a child.
(nautical) To lie to in heavy weather under just sufficient sail to head into the wind.
To strain; to subject to excessive tests.
examples: The light tries his eyes.
Repeated failures try one's patience.

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly African-American Vernacular, used with another verb) To want
examples: I am really not trying to hear you talk about my mama like that.

adjectives.description: try (comparative more try, superlative most try)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Fine, excellent.
